facts.text: The New England Revolution is one of the ten charter clubs of Major League Soccer (MLS), having competed since the league's inaugural season.
The club is owned by Robert Kraft, who also owns the New England Patriots.
The New England Revolution won their first major trophy in the 2007 U.S. Open Cup.
The Revolution won the 2008 North American SuperLiga.
The New England Revolution won their first Supporters' Shield in 2021.
The Revolution have participated in five MLS Cup finals (2002, 2005, 2006, 2007, and 2014) without winning the MLS Cup, the most of any club.
Bert Patenaude, from Fall River, Massachusetts, scored the first hat-trick in World Cup play at the inaugural FIFA World Cup in 1930.
The USMNT finished in third place at the 1930 FIFA World Cup.
Robert Kraft became the founding investor/operator of the New England Revolution on June 6, 1995.
Frank Stapleton was selected as the Revolution's first head coach on January 4, 1996.
The Revolution played their first-ever league match on April 13, 1996, a 3–2 loss to the Tampa Bay Mutiny.
Robert Ukrop scored the Revolution's first goal in club history in their first-ever league match.
The Revolution recorded their first-ever club win on April 20, 1996, a 1–0 victory over the MetroStars.
The New England Revolution failed to make the playoffs in their inaugural season despite having U.S. Men's National Team regulars like Alexi Lalas, Mike Burns, and Joe-Max Moore on their team.
Thomas Rongen was appointed as the head coach of the New England Revolution in November following the inaugural season.
The New England Revolution qualified for the playoffs for the first time in team history in 1997.
The Revolution participated in the first three-team trade in MLS history in February 1998, ultimately signing Raúl Díaz Arce.
Walter Zenga was named the league's first player-manager on October 28, 1998.
The New England Revolution made history in the 2000 U.S. Open Cup by becoming the first-ever MLS team to lose to an amateur club, the Mid Michigan Bucks.
The Revolution reached the final of the 2001 U.S. Open Cup but lost to the Los Angeles Galaxy on a golden goal by Danny Califf.
Steve Nicol's era as head coach of the New England Revolution began in 2002 and lasted until 2011.
Steve Nicol was appointed as the full-time head coach of the New England Revolution during the 2002 season.
Under Steve Nicol, the New England Revolution made it to the playoffs for eight straight seasons, starting from his full-time appointment in 2002 until 2010.
The New England Revolution appeared in three consecutive MLS Cup finals from 2005 to 2007 under Steve Nicol's coaching.
In the MLS Cup 2002, the New England Revolution were defeated by the Galaxy 1–0 on a golden goal by Carlos Ruiz.
The 2002 MLS Cup final, held at Gillette Stadium and attended by 61,316 spectators, was the largest figure for any MLS Cup until MLS Cup 2018.
Craig Tornberg was officially named the General Manager of the New England Revolution on December 16, 2003.
Chris Brown scored the Revolution's 3rd all-time hat trick against the Chicago Fire on August 31, 2003, in a 5–1 win.
José Cancela was signed by the New England Revolution from Deportivo Saprissa in July 2003.
Gillette Stadium hosted a double-header on July 27, 2003, featuring FC Barcelona vs. Juventus FC followed by New England Revolution vs. DC United.
The New England Revolution set new club records for goals in a half (4) and total goals scored (6) in their 6–1 victory over Colorado Rapids on September 18.
Paul Mariner joined Steve Nicol's staff as an assistant coach in 2004.
The New England Revolution finished tops in the Eastern Conference and lost the MLS Cup final to Los Angeles 1–0 in extra time again in 2005.
The New England Revolution lost MLS Cup 2006 to the Houston Dynamo in penalty kicks after the game was tied 1–1 in extra time.
The New England Revolution participated in the 2003 CONCACAF Champions Cup but were eliminated by LD Alajuelense with a 5:3 aggregate score after two away games.
The New England Revolution played their "home" game against LD Alajuelense in the 2006 CONCACAF Champions' Cup in Bermuda on February 22, 2006.
The New England Revolution reached two cup finals in the 2007 season, including the MLS Cup, where they were defeated by Houston 2–1.
Clint Dempsey was sold to Fulham F.C. for a club and league record fee of $4m in the 2007 pre-season.
Jose Cancela was lost to Toronto FC in the 2006 MLS expansion draft.
The New England Revolution made a joint-highest 6 selections in the 2007 MLS Superdraft.
Adam Cristman was a finalist for the 2007 MLS Rookie of the Year.
Eddie Johnson became the first MLS player to net three times in back-to-back matches in May 2007.
The regular-season match between New England Revolution and LA Galaxy in August 2007 drew a crowd of 35,402 fans, the highest-ever for a regular season home game for the Revolution.
Michael Parkhurst's goal against Toronto FC was named a finalist for the 2007 MLS Goal of the Year Award.
The New England Revolution finished second in the Eastern Conference in the 2007 season with a 14–8–8 record.
Michael Parkhurst won both MLS Defender of the Year and MLS Humanitarian of the Year in 2007.

The New England Revolution faced Houston Dynamo in the MLS Cup on November 18, 2007, marking the first time in league history the championship match was contended between the same sides in back-to-back years.
The New England Revolution switched their formation from 4–4–2 to 3–5–2 in the second half of a notable game.
Brian Ching was chosen over Taylor Twellman for the 2006 FIFA World Cup USA Squad.
The New England Revolution hold the record for most losses in MLS Cup games.
The New England Revolution won their first-ever trophy, the 2007 U.S. Open Cup, by defeating FC Dallas 3–2.
Andy Dorman signed with St Mirren F.C. in the Scottish Premiership after the 2007 season.
Pat Noonan signed with Aalesunds FK in the Norwegian Eliteserien for the 2008 season.
James Riley was selected by San Jose Earthquakes in the 2007 MLS expansion draft.
The New England Revolution traded long-time defender Joe Franchino to the LA Galaxy in exchange for a second-round 2009 MLS Superdraft pick in April 2008.
The New England Revolution traded for 3-time MLS Cup Champion defender and U.S. international Chris Albright.
The New England Revolution's 2007 U.S. Open Cup victory qualified them for the preliminary round of the newly expanded CONCACAF Champions League and SuperLiga 2008.
The New England Revolution competed in four different competitions during the 2008 season: MLS, Open Cup, Champions League, and SuperLiga.
The New England Revolution won the 2008 SuperLiga, defeating Houston Dynamo in the final on penalties.
Members of the New England Revolution subdued a disruptive passenger on American Flight 725 in July 2008 while traveling to a Group B match against Chivas USA.
In the 2008 Champions League, the New England Revolution were eliminated by Joe Public FC of Trinidad and Tobago with an aggregate score of 6-1.
The New England Revolution won the SuperLiga trophy in 2008 but were defeated in the first round of the MLS playoffs by the Chicago Fire with a 3-0 aggregate score.
Michael Parkhurst left the New England Revolution for FC Nordsjælland at the end of his contract in 2008.
Khano Smith was selected by Seattle Sounders FC in the expansion draft following the 2008 MLS season.

In the 2009 MLS SuperDraft, the New England Revolution made seven total selections, including defenders Kevin Alston and Darrius Barnes, with Barnes becoming the only rookie in MLS to play every minute of the 2009 season.
Taylor Twellman became the 5th player in Major League Soccer history to record 100 goals on June 7, 2009, in a match against the New York Red Bulls.
The New England Revolution's loss to Real Salt Lake by 6-0 at Rio Tinto Stadium in 2009 was the heaviest defeat in the club's history up to that point.
Shalrie Joseph was the top scorer for the New England Revolution in the 2009 regular season with 8 goals and was named to the 2009 MLS All-Star Game roster.
The New England Revolution's last playoff appearance before a four-year absence was in 2009, where they were eliminated by the Chicago Fire in the Eastern Conference Semifinals.
Steve Ralston retired from the New England Revolution after the 2009 season, having played a league-leading 378 matches.
Preston Burpo was traded to the New England Revolution in exchange for Jeff Larentowicz and Wells Thompson.
In the 2010 MLS SuperDraft, the New England Revolution selected Zack Schilawski and Seth Sinovic with their first and second round picks, respectively.
Marko Perović was the New England Revolution's lead scorer in 2010 and won the team's 2010 MVP award.
Steve Nicol recorded his 100th win as Revolution manager on April 10, 2010, becoming only the third coach in MLS history to reach 100 wins.
Zack Schilawski scored the ninth hat trick in Revolution history on April 10, 2010, against Toronto FC.
The New England Revolution made it to the 2010 North American SuperLiga final but lost to Monarcas Morelia 2-1 on September 1, 2010.
The 2011 season was the worst in the New England Revolution's history, finishing at the bottom of the Eastern Conference.
Taylor Twellman retired on November 3, 2010, as the Revolution's top scorer and the sixth highest scorer in MLS history with 101 goals.
Diego Fagúndez was signed as the New England Revolution's first ever homegrown player on November 15, 2010.
The club signed Didier Domi from Olympiacos F.C. and Ousmane Dabo, who had been a free agent, in January before the 2011 MLS season.
The club made five selections in the 2011 MLS SuperDraft, using its sixth overall pick on defender A.J. Soares.
The club's first win of the 2011 season came on March 26, 2011, with a 2–0 victory over DC United.
Benny Feilhaber, a U.S. international, joined the club via allocation ranking in April 2011.
The club's first-ever Designated Player was Milton Caraglio, signed during the summer transfer window of 2011.
The club failed to make the playoffs in 2011 and parted ways with manager Steve Nicol at the end of the season, who had managed the team for a league-record 10 years.
Steve Nicol delivered the club its first two pieces of silverware in its history during his tenure.
Brian Bilello was promoted to the position of club President of the Revolution on November 9, 2011.
Mike Burns was promoted to the position of General Manager of the Revolution on November 9, 2011.
Jay Heaps was hired as the head coach of the Revolution on November 15, 2011.
Jay Heaps' first career victory as head coach came on March 24, 2012, in a 1–0 win over the Portland Timbers.
Saër Sène was the Revolution's top scorer in 2012 with 11 goals.
The Revolution attempted to sign Jose Moreno Mora on loan from Once Caldas in the 2011-12 offseason.
Jose Moreno Mora scored his only goal for the Revolution on April 14 in a 2–1 defeat to DC United.
Shalrie Joseph departed the Revolution in the 2012 season after spending 10 years with the club.
Jerry Bengtson was added as a Designated Player by the Revolution in early July 2012.
The Revolution snapped a ten-game winless streak on September 5, 2012, thanks to Dimitry Imbongo's first MLS goal.
Lee Nguyen was added to the Revolution via a weighted lottery.
Kelyn Rowe was acquired by the Revolution via the MLS SuperDraft.
José Gonçalves, who became a 2013 MLS Best XI defender, was added to the Revolution's roster.
Scott Caldwell was added to the Revolution as a U.S. U18 international and homegrown player.
Juan Agudelo and Charlie Davies, both U.S. internationals, were added to the Revolution's roster.
Andrew Farrell was the Revolution's first-ever 1st-overall draft pick.
In 2013, the New England Revolution finished in 3rd place in the Eastern Conference, making the playoffs for the first time since 2009.
Diego Fagúndez led the New England Revolution with 13 goals and added 7 assists during the 2013 campaign.
The New England Revolution's 2013 season ended in the Eastern Conference semifinal round with a 4–3 aggregate defeat to Sporting Kansas City.
Matt Reis announced his retirement following the conclusion of the 2013 season.
Kevin Alston was named MLS Comeback Player of the Year in December 2013 after returning from his battle with chronic myelogenous leukemia.
The New England Revolution went on a 5-game winning streak in May 2014, their longest in nearly a decade.
The New England Revolution signed U.S. national team member Jermaine Jones in late August 2014 on a designated player contract.
The Revolution finished in 2nd place in the regular season in the Eastern Conference in 2014.
Bobby Shuttleworth led the 2014 MLS Cup Playoffs in saves with a total of 18.
The New England Revolution made it to the MLS Cup Final for the first time since 2007 during the 2014 season.
The New England Revolution lost to the LA Galaxy in the MLS Cup Final on December 7, 2014, by a score of 2–1.
The 2014 MLS Cup loss marked the New England Revolution's fifth loss in five MLS Cup Final appearances.
The New England Revolution established a "strategic partnership" with Sporting CP in 2014.

Brad Friedel was announced as the head coach of the New England Revolution in November 2017.
The New England Revolution traded Kei Kamara to Vancouver Whitecaps FC in exchange for a 2019 first round draft pick and a conditional 2020 second round pick during the 2018 pre-season.
Cristian Penilla was brought in on loan from C.F. Pachuca by the New England Revolution for the 2018 season.
Lee Nguyen was traded to Los Angeles FC on May 1, 2018, in exchange for $350,000 in General Allocation Money and $350,000 in Targeted Allocation Money.
Brad Friedel's first win as head coach of the New England Revolution came on March 10, 2018, with a 2–1 victory over the Colorado Rapids.
The New England Revolution had a season-high attendance of 36,573 on July 14, 2018, against the LA Galaxy.
Matt Turner recorded his first MLS clean sheet on March 31, 2018, in a 2–0 win against Houston Dynamo FC.
Cristian Penilla was named the New England Revolution's JetBlue Team MVP, Players' Player of the Year, and won the Golden Boot Award in 2018.
The New England Revolution finished in 8th place in the Eastern Conference in the 2018 season.
Carles Gil was added to the New England Revolution for a then-club record fee of $2 million before the 2019 season.
Tajon Buchanan was a 1st round draft pick by the New England Revolution in the 2019 pre-season.
The New England Revolution had only 8 points through match week 12 of the 2019 season.
Brad Friedel was fired by the New England Revolution on May 9, 2019, after a 12–21–13 career record.
Bruce Arena was announced as the head coach and sporting director of the New England Revolution on May 14, 2019.
Under Bruce Arena, the New England Revolution went eleven games undefeated until losing to Los Angeles FC on August 3, 2019.
The New England Revolution qualified for the playoffs in 2019 for the first time since 2015.
Gustavo Bou was signed by the New England Revolution for a club-record fee reportedly in the range of $6–7 million from Club Tijuana in 2019.
The New England Revolution were eliminated in the 1st Round of the 2019 Playoffs by Atlanta United FC with a 1–0 defeat.
Adam Buksa was added to the New England Revolution squad for $4.5 million as a Designated Player before the 2020 season.
The New England Revolution recorded their first win of the 2020 season in the MLS is Back Tournament group stage.
The New England Revolution defeated the Montreal Impact 2–1 in the 2020 MLS Cup Playoffs play-in round.
The New England Revolution advanced to the Eastern Conference Finals for the first time in 7 years during the 2020 MLS Cup Playoffs.
Matt Turner finished second in MLS Goalkeeper of the Year voting for 2020.
The New England Revolution were eliminated from the 2020 MLS Cup Playoffs by the Columbus Crew, who would eventually win the MLS Cup 2020.

Bruce Arena was suspended by The Revolution on August 1, 2023, due to reports of inappropriate and insensitive remarks.
Bruce Arena resigned from The Revolution following a six-week investigation on September 9, 2023.
Richie Williams served as interim coach of The Revolution until September 12, 2023, when Clint Peay was announced as the new interim manager.
Under Clint Peay's tenure, The Revolution finished 5th in the Eastern Conference during the 2023 season.

The Revolution's attendance for the regular season finale against the Philadelphia Union on 2023 was 41,355, marking the second-highest ever for a regular-season match and the third-highest in single-match attendance history for the club.
The Revolution set a new club record for single-season average home attendance in 2023 with 23,940.
Curt Onalfo was elevated from interim to full-time Sporting Director of the Revolution on November 30, 2023.
Caleb Porter was appointed as the head coach of the Revolution on December 19, 2023.
The Revolution purchased Designated Player Tomás Chancalay for $3.1 million in November following his loan to the club in the 2023 Summer Transfer Window.
Gustavo Bou concluded his Revolution career with 48 goals and 21 assists in 108 league appearances over four seasons.
The Revolution's first win under Caleb Porter came on February 21, 2024, with a 1–0 victory over C.A. Independiente de La Chorrera in the 2024 CONCACAF Champions Cup.
The Revolution's first league win under Caleb Porter occurred on April 6, 2024, with a 1–0 home win against Charlotte FC.
The Revolution set a new single-match attendance record of 65,612 on April 27, 2024, in their match against Inter Miami CF and Lionel Messi.
The Revolution finished the 2024 season with an average attendance of 29,262, a club record high.
The Revolution were eliminated from post-season contention on October 5, 2024, with three matches left to play.
Inter Miami broke the Revolution's 2021 single-season points record with a win over the Revolution in their final match of the season.
The Revolution's original club badge was based on the flag of the United States and mirrored the 1994 FIFA World Cup logo.
The Revolution launched its new logo in 2021, featuring an "R" sitting above a red strikethrough, with design elements paying homage to the original logo and symbolizing defiance.
The New England Revolution wore red shorts in their first year, 1996, and then again to mark their 25th anniversary during the 2020 and 2021 seasons.
The New England Revolution introduced a red away jersey with white and green accents in 2015, in tribute to the flag of New England.
Gillette Stadium, with a seating capacity of 66,000, became the home of the New England Revolution in 2002, replacing Foxboro Stadium.
The largest stand-alone MLS post-season crowd at a Revolution game was 61,316 during the 2002 MLS Cup final against the Los Angeles Galaxy at Gillette Stadium.
Gillette Stadium's FieldTurf surface was upgraded in April 2014 to FieldTurf "Revolution" with a "VersaTile" drainage system and has a FIFA two-star quality rating.
Robert Kraft announced the opening of a new $35 million training center for the New England Revolution in 2019.
Major League Soccer announced on June 14, 2006, that it would begin working with the Kraft Family to identify sites for a soccer-specific stadium for the Revolution.
Preliminary discussions about building a 50,000 to 55,000-seat stadium in Somerville for the Revolution were reported on August 2, 2007.
In July 2010, Kraft mentioned that over $1 million had been invested in finding a suitable site for a new soccer-specific stadium, preferably in the urban core of Boston.

On November 14, 2023, it was announced that language for converting a parcel into a professional soccer stadium and a waterfront park in Everett, Massachusetts was included in a supplemental budget released by the Massachusetts Senate.
State Senator Sal DiDomenico introduced a bill with the intent to convert a parcel into a professional soccer stadium in Everett, Massachusetts on December 21, 2023.

A public hearing regarding the New England Revolution's stadium plans in Everett, Massachusetts was held with the Massachusetts Legislature's Joint Committee on Economic Development and Emerging Technologies on April 2, 2024.
The measure for the New England Revolution's new stadium in Everett, Massachusetts died at the end of the formal session in 2024 due to lack of House-Senate agreement.

The Massachusetts legislature announced on November 12, 2024, that a provision for removing the Everett 43-acre parcel of land's "Designated Port Area" distinction was included in the economic development bond bill.
The New England Revolution formed a reserve team, New England Revolution II, in USL League One, which began play in the 2020 season.
Clint Peay was announced as the first manager of New England Revolution II on November 25, 2019.
The New England Revolution joined the inaugural 21-team MLS Next Pro season starting in 2022.
The New England Revolution Academy is recognized by U.S. Soccer as one of the top 10 youth development programs in the country.
Diego Fagúndez was the Revolution's first ever MLS Homegrown Player Rule signing in 2010.
Esmir Bajraktarevic was sold by New England Revolution to Dutch club PSV Eindhoven on January 2, 2025, in a deal reportedly worth up to $6 million.
The New England Revolution's supporters' clubs are called the "Midnight Riders" and "The Rebellion," with the "Midnight Riders" name honoring the rides of Paul Revere and William Dawes.
The End Zone Militia, a group of American Revolutionary War reenactors, was founded in 1996 and is employed by the New England Revolution to ceremoniously fire muskets when the team scores a goal.
The New England Revolution's main rival is considered to be the New York Red Bulls.
The New England Revolution had a 20 match undefeated streak against the Red Bulls at Gillette Stadium that ended on June 8, 2014.
New England Revolution fans considered the Chicago Fire the team's most bitter rival in a 2009 poll on the club's official site.
New York City FC knocked out the Revolution in the eastern conference semifinals of the 2021 MLS Cup Playoffs.
From 2021 to 2022, Revolution matches were televised locally on either WBZ-TV or WSBK-TV.
